sources.title: Articles on Smashing Magazine — For Web Designers And Developers

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Geoff Graham)
articles.description: CSS is evolving faster than ever. With all of the new features that are now available — and forthcoming — since we got Flexbox and Grid years ago, the way we write CSS is evolving, too. In this article, Geoff Graham shares which features have had the most influence on his current approaches to CSS, as well as those that have not (at least yet).
articles.title: Writing CSS In 2023: Is It Any Different Than A Few Years Ago?

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Devin Harold)
articles.description: Accelerate your organization’s growth and innovation with the power of Rapid Research. From inception to implementation, here is the step-by-step roadmap on how to build the program from scratch and uncover the untapped ROI opportunities waiting to propel your initiatives to new heights.
articles.title: How To Create A Rapid Research Program To Support Insights At Scale

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Drew McLellan)
articles.description: In this episode of The Smashing Podcast, we’re talking about The Transitional Web. What is it, and how does it describe the technologies we’re using? Drew McLellan talks to Chris Ferdinandi to find out.
articles.title: Smashing Podcast Episode 63 With Chris Ferdinandi: What Is The Transitional Web?

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Andy Budd)
articles.description: In this article, Andy Budd, curator of UX London and Leading Design conferences, outlines some of the things that make a potentially amazing presentation, as well as a few big gotchas. If you’ve ever wondered what it takes to get a speaking slot at a conference, this article is for you.
articles.title: How To Become A Better Speaker At Conferences

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Temani Afif)
articles.description: CSS has all kinds of tricks that are capable of turning images into neat, interactive elements. This article is a collection of fancy 3D effects for images that demonstrate those CSS powers.
articles.title: Shines, Perspective, And Rotations: Fancy CSS 3D Effects For Images

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Robert Goesch)
articles.description: As of today, the world’s 50 top airlines have all agreed on the same flight search pattern. Yet the path to booking the right flight remains frustrating and confusing. Is there really only one solution? Or are they afraid to break the mold? Explore the thought experiment which turned the seemingly untouchable pattern on its head.
articles.title: The UX Of Flight Searches: How We Challenged Industry Standards

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Cosima Mielke & Geoff Graham)
articles.description: How can we create products and experiences that don’t cause harm to the planet and to the people who use them? What do we need to consider to make more sustainable design decisions and reduce the carbon footprint of our websites? In this post, we compiled valuable resources that will get you familiar with the principles of sustainable design.
articles.title: Sustainable Design Toolkits And Resources

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Cosima Mielke)
articles.description: Let’s welcome the new month with some fresh desktop wallpapers. Designed by artists and designers from around the globe, they come in versions with and without a calendar for July 2023. Enjoy!
articles.title: Off To New Adventures (July 2023 Wallpapers Edition)

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Vitaly Friedman)
articles.description: The design process is messy. You might be following a structured approach, but too often, it takes a life of its own. And before you know it, you are designing in chaos, with last-minute changes and missed deadlines. So, what’s the “perfect” design process?
articles.title: What’s The Perfect Design Process?

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Patrick Brosset)
articles.description: Let’s discover the most popular DevTools tips that can boost your productivity and revolutionize your debugging workflow.
articles.title: Useful DevTools Tips and Tricks

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Mikołaj Dobrucki)
articles.description: In today’s article, let’s explore how we can use Flex Layout and see how it empowers designers with greater control over their work while saving everyone’s time.
articles.title: Penpot’s Flex Layout: Building CSS Layouts In A Design Tool

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Geoff Graham)
articles.description: The Wikipedia team shipped a redesign of the ubiquitous and one of the [most visited websites](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_most_visited_websites) on the web. Alex Hollendar and Jon Robson led the work and generously discussed the effort with us in a thorough, wide-ranging interview that covers the design, development, and processes that went into the project.
articles.title: Behind The Curtains Of Wikipedia Redesign

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Joas Pambou)
articles.description: Dive into an article where you will build an app that evaluates audio files for positive and negative sentiments. The idea is that you will create an interface for uploading an audio file, then transcribe the contents into text before analyzing the text and assigning it a positive or negative score for how the tone is perceived.
articles.title: Using AI To Detect Sentiment In Audio Files

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Scott Gallant)
articles.description: Visual editing is beginning to make its way into headless architecture and the early results look promising. We’ll look at a few headless CMSs that currently support visual editing in this article.
articles.title: Visual Editing Comes To The Headless CMS

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Juan Diego Rodríguez)
articles.description: Part 2 of the series concentrates on implementing internationalization (i18n) on a Gatsby website, an essential feature on any multilingual website that can be quite a bit of trouble if incorrectly implemented, creating more problems than it solves.
articles.title: Gatsby Headaches And How To Cure Them: i18n (Part 2)

articles.author: info@thehackernews.com (The Hacker News)
articles.description:
The Russia-linked threat actor known as Gamaredon has been observed conducting data exfiltration activities within an hour of the initial compromise.
"As a vector of primary compromise, for the most part, emails and messages in messengers (Telegram, WhatsApp, Signal) are used, in most cases, using previously compromised accounts," the Computer Emergency Response Team of Ukraine (CERT-UA) said in
articles.title: CERT-UA Uncovers Gamaredon's Rapid Data Exfiltration Tactics Following Initial Compromise

articles.author: info@thehackernews.com (The Hacker News)
articles.description:
With generative artificial intelligence (AI) becoming all the rage these days, it's perhaps not surprising that the technology has been repurposed by malicious actors to their own advantage, enabling avenues for accelerated cybercrime.

articles.title: Iranian Hackers Charming Kitten Utilize POWERSTAR Backdoor in Targeted Espionage Attacks

articles.description: In today's fast-paced digital landscape, the widespread adoption of AI (Artificial Intelligence) tools is transforming the way organizations operate. articles.title: 3 Reasons SaaS Security is the Imperative First Step to Ensuring Secure AI Usage

Meta's WhatsApp has rolled out updates to its proxy feature, allowing more flexibility in the kind of content that can be shared in conversations.
This includes the ability to send and receive images, voice notes, files, stickers and GIFs, WhatsApp told The Hacker News. The new features were first reported by BBC Persian.

An active financially motivated campaign is targeting vulnerable SSH servers to covertly ensnare them into a proxy network.
"This is an active campaign in which the attacker leverages SSH for remote access, running malicious scripts that stealthily enlist victim servers into a peer-to-peer (P2P) proxy network, such as Peer2Profit or Honeygain," Akamai researcher Allen West said in a Thursday
articles.title: Cybercriminals Hijacking Vulnerable SSH Servers in New Proxyjacking Campaign

articles.description:
MITRE has released its annual list of the Top 25 "most dangerous software weaknesses" for the year 2023.
"These weaknesses lead to serious vulnerabilities in software," the U.S. Cybersecurity and Infrastructure Security Agency (CISA) said. "An attacker can often exploit these vulnerabilities to take control of an affected system, steal data, or prevent applications from working."

articles.title: MITRE Unveils Top 25 Most Dangerous Software Weaknesses of 2023: Are You at Risk?

articles.description:
The Iranian state-sponsored group dubbed MuddyWater has been attributed to a previously unseen command-and-control (C2) framework called PhonyC2 that's been put to use by the actor since 2021.

articles.title: From MuddyC3 to PhonyC2: Iran's MuddyWater Evolves with a New Cyber Weapon

articles.description:
Cybersecurity researchers have shared the inner workings of an Android malware family called Fluhorse.
The malware "represents a significant shift as it incorporates the malicious components directly within the Flutter code," Fortinet FortiGuard Labs researcher Axelle Apvrille said in a report published last week.

articles.title: Fluhorse: Flutter-Based Android Malware Targets Credit Cards and 2FA Codes

Cyber threat intelligence is an effective weapon in the ongoing battle to protect digital assets and infrastructure - especially when combined with AI. But AI is only as good as the data feeding it. Access to unique, underground sources is key.

The North Korea-aligned threat actor known as Andariel leveraged a previously undocumented malware called EarlyRat in attacks exploiting the Log4j Log4Shell vulnerability last year.
"Andariel infects machines by executing a Log4j exploit, which, in turn, downloads further malware from the command-and-control (C2) server," Kaspersky said in a new report.
Also called Silent Chollima and Stonefly,
articles.title: North Korean Hacker Group Andariel Strikes with New EarlyRat Malware

Fortinet FortiGuard Labs, which made the discovery, said it found the malware in an executable that masqueraded as a PDF file with a Russian name "CMK Правила оформления больничных листов.pdf.exe," which translates to "CMK
articles.title: Newly Uncovered ThirdEye Windows-Based Malware Steals Sensitive Data

articles.description:
Drones that don't have any known security weaknesses could be the target of electromagnetic fault injection (EMFI) attacks, potentially enabling a threat actor to achieve arbitrary code execution and compromise their functionality and safety.

articles.title: Alert: New Electromagnetic Attacks on Drones Could Let Attackers Take Control

articles.description:
Cybersecurity researchers have exposed the workings of a scam ring called CryptosLabs that's estimated to have made €480 million in illegal profits by targeting users in French-speaking individuals in France, Belgium, and Luxembourg since April 2018.

articles.title: 5 Things CISOs Need to Know About Securing OT Environments

articles.title: 8Base Ransomware Spikes in Activity, Threatens U.S. and Brazilian Businesses

articles.title: New Mockingjay Process Injection Technique Could Let Malware Evade Detection

articles.title: New Ongoing Campaign Targets npm Ecosystem with Unique Execution Chain

articles.title: EncroChat Bust Leads to 6,558 Criminals' Arrests and €900 Million Seizure

articles.title: Researchers Find Way to Recover Cryptographic Keys by Analyzing LED Flickers

articles.title: Japanese Cryptocurrency Exchange Falls Victim to JokerSpy macOS Backdoor Attack

articles.title: How Generative AI Can Dupe SaaS Authentication Protocols — And Effective Ways To Prevent Other Key AI Risks in SaaS

articles.title: Microsoft Warns of Widescale Credential Stealing Attacks by Russian Hackers

articles.title: Powerful JavaScript Dropper PindOS Distributes Bumblebee and IcedID Malware

articles.title: NSA Releases Guide to Combat Powerful BlackLotus Bootkit Targeting Windows Systems

articles.description:
Internet-facing Linux systems and Internet of Things (IoT) devices are being targeted as part of a new campaign designed to illicitly mine cryptocurrency.

articles.title: MULTI#STORM Campaign Targets India and U.S. with Remote Access Trojans

articles.title: Alert: Million of GitHub Repositories Likely Vulnerable to RepoJacking Attack

articles.title: ScarCruft Hackers Exploit Ably Service for Stealthy Wiretapping Attacks

articles.description:
If Jesus was my Copilot, what would he do?

Opinion  Open source. It's open. You can look. Mostly, you can use. There's a clue in the name. Not so fast, claims a class action brought against Microsoft, OpenAI and GitHub. Copilot, an in-IDE AI-powered and open source trained suggestion bot, works by offering lines of code to programmers - and that, the class action suit alleges, breaks the rules, and is being sneaky in trying to hide it. A judge has ruled that some of the claims deserve their day in court. Dear lord, not another copyright battle.…
articles.title: Whose line is it anyway, GitHub? Innovation, not litigation, should answer
